授業目的: The purpose of this course is that students will acquire knowledge and understand global development agenda--an important transition from the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and complex implementation aspects of SDGs, which contains 17 goals and 169 targets adopted by the UN's 193 member states in 2015.
到達目標:
1. Students will be able to assess the transition from MDGs to SDGs.
2. Students will be able to research integrated three policy pillars of “Economics, “Environment, and “Social” plus governance to implement SDGs.
3. Students will be able to understand the policy direction of UN development system at large under and the leadership of Secretary General.
特記事項: 【合併】中国企業会計（国際学研究科前期）/アジア会計論特殊講義（商学研究科前期）/International Public Policy　（大学院共通科目・認定科目前期）/International Public Policy（国際学研究科前期）/国際公共政策論　（司法研究科）/International Public Policy　（経営戦略研究科）/Management of International Organizations　（大学院共通科目・認定科目前期）/Management of International Organizations（国際学研究科前期）/国際組織運営論　（司法研究科）/Management of International Organizations　（経営戦略研究科）/Global Sustainable Development　（大学院共通科目・認定科目前期）/Global Sustainable Development（国際学研究科前期）/Global Sustainable Development　（経営戦略研究科）
関連科目: UN and Foreign Affairs related courses
授業の概要・背景: Some of the key features of SDGs that differentiate them from MDGs include (i) emphasis on no one being left behind; (ii) accountabilities of both developing and developed countries; (iii) widening scope from poverty reduction to sustainable development; (iv) inclusion of COVID-19, human rights, peace and security, etc. which were included in the Millennium Declaration of 2000 but not in the MDGs; and (v) identifying the means of implementation for each goal. A wide range of means of implementation of SDGs is outlined. The course will discuss how the global consensus was built, how feasible SDGs may be, what strategies would be used for their achievement, and what are the major stakeholders' interests and their engagement.
授業方法: This course is conducted by "Face to Face "format. The class will be held in seminar/lecture style. Resource person(s) would encourage students for active class discussion in focusing on selected topics. Students' presentation would be requested in each module. The course will be taught by UN and other international practitioners and experts with hands-on experience in development.

Middle- Income Trap:
Recently, the newly coined term middle-income trap has been widely used by policy makers to refer to the economies that seem to be stuck in the middle-income range. The discussion in the class include the examination of the middle-income trap hypothesis and the identification of the variables that could alter growth.
